uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools
Class Theme

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools.Theme
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.EventListener, FilterChangedListener, HighlightChangedListener, HighlightPositionChangedListener, LayerChangedListener, SelectionChangedListener, SelectionPositionChangedListener, SelectionRegionChangedListener, java.io.Serializable, ShaderChangedListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
MultiTheme
public class Theme
extends java.lang.Object
implements FilterChangedListener, SelectionPositionChangedListener, HighlightPositionChangedListener, HighlightChangedListener, LayerChangedListener, SelectionChangedListener, SelectionRegionChangedListener, ShaderChangedListener, java.io.Serializable

A theme holds all of the information needed by a viewer to display a thematic map, including a layer, shadeing and highlightng scheem. A theme acts as a container for all of the aspects that make up a thematic display of a geographic feature. It also handles all of the comunication between viewers, layers and some highlights. Any clicks in the viewer can be set to pass to a theme where it will be converted to an ID from the layer and then finaly set in the highlightManager. Once constructed a theme can be added to multiple viewers without problems.

There are a number of parts that make up a theme, and this is reflected by the number of constructers, the following is a list of all the parts.
Constructors that lack parts will make their own as needed.

The main parts that make up a full theme are:

  • layer: Contains the geographic features for this theme.
  • shade: Defines the shading scheme to use when displaying.
  • data: The GeoData that will provide data to the layer.
  • style: Defines how a feature should be painted.
  • highlightStyle: Defines how highlighting should look.
  • selectionStyle: Defines how selections should look.
  • highlight: A highlight manager, probably shared with other themes
  • selectionMgr: A selection manager, can be shared with other themes
  • name: A name for this theme.

See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

Theme

public Theme(Layer l,
             Shader s,
             java.lang.String n,
             HighlightManager hm,
             GeoData d,
             GeoData t,
             ShadeStyle style)
A full constructor for a theme, requiering the provision of all parts.
Parameters:
l - The layer containing the geographic features.
s - The shader to use when colouring in the layer.
n - A String describing or nameing this theme.
hm - A HighlightManager, clicks in the viewer converted into highlight requests.
d - The GeoData object to base link feature IDs in the layer with attribute values.
t - The GeoData object to base link feature IDs in the layer with ToolTip info.
style - A ShadeStyle object to pass to the layer.

Theme

public Theme()
The default constructor lacks too many of the requred paramiters to be of general use.

Theme

public Theme(Layer l)
Constructs a very simple mono shaded (lightGray) theme from the given layer. It will have no name,highlightManager or data and all features will be shaded light gray
Parameters:
l - the Layer to base this theme on.

Theme

public Theme(Layer l,
             Shader s)
Constructs a simple theme from a layer and a shader. As this theme has no GeoData object this constructor only makes sence if the layer has its own built in data or if the shader is designed to give sensible shading from the feature IDs alone.
Parameters:
l - The layer to base this theme on.
s - A shader for this theme.

Theme

public Theme(Layer l,
             Shader s,
             java.lang.String n)
Constructs a simple named theme from a layer and a shader. As this theme has no GeoData object this constructor only makes sence if the layer has its own built in data or if the shader is designed to give sensible shading from the feature IDs alone.
Parameters:
l - The layer to base this theme on.
s - A shader for this theme.
n - A String that names this shader

Theme

public Theme(Layer l,
             Shader s,
             java.lang.String n,
             HighlightManager hm)
Constructs a named theme from a layer and a shader. Linked displays can be constructed if a theme in a different viewer shares the same HighlightManager.
Parameters:
l - The layer to base this theme on.
s - A shader for this theme.
n - A String that names this shader
hm - The HighlightManager to comunicarte highlight requests through.

setTipData

public void setTipData(GeoData t)
Viewers have the ability to display short popup messages in the form of tool tips when the users mouse rests over features in the map.

By setting the TipData for a theme it is posible to set what this string should be for each feature.
The GeoData supplied to this method sould assosiate feature ids found in this theme with numeric or string values to display in the tool tips.

An example of use might be:
theme.setTipData(shapefileReader.readData("Names"));

Parameters:
d - A GeoData containing the new Tool Tip data for this theme.
See Also:
getTipText(int)

setComplexTipData

public void setComplexTipData(GeoData[] t,
                              java.lang.String ts)
Viewers have the ability to display short popup messages in the form of tool tips when the users mouse rests over features in the map.

This method provides flexible tooltips at the expence of being a little less straight forward than setTipData().
To construct setup a tooltip this method needs a format string wich is a string containing special characters that will be parsed, and an array of GeoData columns to be put into the formatstring when the tooltip is shown

An example of use might be:
TooltipArray[0]=shapefileReader.readData("Country"); TooltipArray[1]=shapefileReader.readData("Population"); theme.setComplexTipData(TooltipArray, "%s: %s");
 This would produce tooltips of the form "Norway: 40000000" when run. Note that more than one element can be used, and static strings can be a part of the tooltip.

Parameters:
t - An array of GeoDatas containing the new Tool Tip data for this theme.
ts - A formatstring.
See Also:
setTipData(uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools.GeoData), getTipText(int)

getGeoData

public GeoData getGeoData()
gets the current geoData.

setFilter

public void setFilter(Filter filter)
Filters can be used to prevent a theme from showing all of the features in the layer it contains. Once a filter is in place, the id of each feature to be ploted is pased to the filter and the feature is only drawn if the filter OKs it.
Parameters:
filter - An implementation of the filter interface that will be used.

getFilter

public Filter getFilter()
Returns the current filter in use by this theme.
Returns:
Filter the current filter, if none has been set then this will be NULL

Parameters:
g - A Graphics context to paint into.
scale - the Scaler to use when displaying this theme

highlightChanged

public void highlightChanged(HighlightChangedEvent hce)
Called to notify this theme that the highlight has changed. Theme will handle notifing all viwers that contain it that its highlight needs repainting.
Required by highlightChangedListener interface and should only be called by a highlighManager.

setHighlight

public void setHighlight(int id)
A convineince method to set the highlight for this theme. A call could be made to the themes HighlightManager directly if it is available, if not this method will do that for you.
Any themes that share this themes HighlightManager will have their highlights changed as well.
Parameters:
id - The int representing the id of the feature to highlight.

Returns:
int The id found at that point.

getTipText

public java.lang.String getTipText(int id)
looks up a short string relating to the feature specified by the provided ID.
Viewer is able to take this string and display it over the feature in the form of a popup tool tip (hence the name).
The data for the tip text is set by calling setTipData.

JM 08/May/2000 updated documentation.

Parameters:
id - An int containing the id of the feature to fetch the tool tip text for.
Returns:
String A short text description for the chosen feature. Returns null if no tipData is set or no feature matches the specifed ID.
See Also:
setTipData(uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools.GeoData), setComplexTipData(uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools.GeoData[], java.lang.String)

getTipText

public java.lang.String getTipText(GeoPoint p,
                                   Scaler scale)
looks up a short string relating to the first feature found to contain the specified point.
Viewer is able to take this string and display it over the feature in the form of a popup tool tip (hence the name).
The data for the tip text is set by calling setTipData.

JM 08/May/2000 updated documentation.

Parameters:
p - A GeoPoint specifing the location of interest to fetch the tool tip text for.
Returns:
String A short text description for the chosen feature. Returns null if no tipData is set or no feature contains the specified point.
See Also:
setTipData(uk.ac.leeds.ccg.geotools.GeoData)

addThemeChangedListener

public void addThemeChangedListener(ThemeChangedListener tcl)
request to be notified of theme changes. Listeners will be notified if any major aspect of this theme changes, the resuting ThemeChangedEvent contains a reson code to describe the nature of the change.
Used by viewers to keep uptodate with their themes.
Parameters:
tcl - a ThemeChangedListener to add

removeThemeChangedListener

public void removeThemeChangedListener(ThemeChangedListener tcl)
request to end being notified of theme changes.
Parameters:
tcl - the ThemeChangedListener to remove.
